Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Measuring Social Vulnerability - Reducing Uncertainty and Validating Indicators

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this collaborative research study is to improve the reliability of social vulnerability indicators by reducing uncertainties in input data and methods, and validating output metrics. Social vulnerability has been receiving increasing attention by disaster planners at local, state, and federal levels as they seek to reduce adverse impacts of natural hazards. Yet far too little is currently understood about the robustness of the leading vulnerability indicators, both in terms of the approaches used to build them and their ability to adequately represent real world conditions. There is a critical need for methodological advancements to improve the precision and accuracy of social vulnerability indicators. Without such advancements, the use of social vulnerability indicators in disaster mitigation, preparedness, and recovery could mislead decision-making. Based on a study area of the Southeast U.S., the project will develop novel regionalization routines and apply global sensitivity analysis and multiple regression to census data inputs and output vulnerability indicators. The research is expected to generate new understanding of the critical inputs and decision points in social vulnerability modeling, the level of agreement of resultant indicators with observed disaster outcomes, and the influence of uncertainty in social vulnerability modeling. By narrowing the existing gap between vulnerability models and real-world practice, improved social vulnerability indicators will allow for better disaster planning and interventions that account for the most vulnerable populations.

The project has great potential to transform dominant approaches for the measurement of social vulnerability to hazards. The finalized methodology will be made widely accessible to both researchers and the public through an internet-GIS application that generates user-customizable vulnerability indices. The improved vulnerability metrics will also be shared with state and federal disaster planners through existing relationships with the research team. The study contributes to training the next generation of hazards researchers through the direct involvement of graduate and undergraduate students, including those from groups historically underrepresented in graduate research and education. The project findings will be integrated into the classroom through the development of learning modules for existing courses that explore urban geography and interactions between hazards and society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided an opportunity to analyze social vulnerability indicators across a series of categories including Employment structure, housing, population structure, race/ethnicity, socio-economic status, and special needs. These characteristics, identified through 100s of disaster case studies, lead to an in (ability) for groups to prepare for, respond to, and rebound from disasters.  A collaborative team of geographers with different specialization worked together on three main themes for this project, each with different outcomes described individually by each PI.  Theme 1: Reduce demographic attribute uncertainty in social vulnerability indicators was overseen by PI Speilman (CU-Boulder); Theme 2: Reduce modeling uncertainty in social vulnerability indicies was overseen by PI Tate (University of Iowa); Theme 3: Validate social vulnerability indicies with empirical data was overseen by PI Emrich (University of Central Florida.  Outcomes listed here are only in reference to Research Theme 3.

Outcomes addressing intellectual merit and broader impact of this work include: 1. The creation of www.vulnerabilitymap.org a freely available web platform for conducting social vulnerability analysis.  This site automatically produces a social vulnerability index, maps, and data for user selected areas of interest.  2. Examples of applications of social vulnerability metrics in real world decision making, including:

a. Florida’s Disaster Recovery Planning Hurricanes Hermine and Matthew Impact Assessment for CDBG-DR ($117 Million) Recovery Action Plan Hurricane Irma Impact Assessment for CDBG-DR ($773 Million) Action Plan - http://www.floridajobs.org/docs/default-source/community-development-files/2018-state-of-florida-cdbg-dr-action-plan-draft.pdf?sfvrsn=2

b. Puerto Rico’s Disaster Recovery Planning Hurricane’s Irma and Maria Impact Assessment for CDBG-DR ($1.5 Billion) Recovery Action Plan and ($8.2 Billion) Recovery Action Plan - http://www.cdbg-dr.pr.gov/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/AP_Amendment_EN_for_Comment-2.pdf

c. South Carolina’s Disaster Recovery Planning 2015 Severe Storms and Flooding Impact Assessment for CDBG-DR ($127 Million) Recovery Action Plan 2016 Hurricane Matthew Impact Assessment for CDBG-DR ($95 Million) Recovery Action Plan - https://www.scdr.sc.gov/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/SC-Severe-Storm-Amendment-4-1-1-18-.pdf

d. West Virginia’s Disaster Recovery Planning Severe Storms and Flooding Impact Assessment for CDBG-DR ($149 Million) Recovery Action Plan - http://www.wvcommerce.org/App_Media/assets/doc/peopleandplaces/disasterrecovery/WV%20Action%20Plan_040317_Proof12.pdf

3. A recently accepted Annals of the Association of American Geographer’s manuscript entitled: “How Valid are Social Vulnerability Models”
